stream_context.summary: Kaze improves engine performance by fixing Mario 64’s culling math and refactoring per-object culling/shadow handling, then spends most of the stream integrating Biobak’s new Star Select (menu) scene: scrolling/tiling background, layout/centering, and text kerning. He also begins implementing Oil Blargg area gameplay logic (fall-into-oil fade-out + respawn), using a triangle edge-distance check generated with ChatGPT, and discusses future polish ideas like a “decal Mario” layer for oil stains.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a clear engine-level optimization/refactor (measurable FPS gain), a near-finished overhaul of the Star Select presentation (a core first-impression UX moment), and a concrete new approach to respawn safety using triangle edge-distance checks (with explicit ChatGPT-assisted workflow).

findings.summary: Kaze fixed a fundamental issue in Mario 64’s culling logic (it culled as if FOV were ~45° while the hack uses ~60°), which previously forced overly conservative culling; correcting it saved ~600 microseconds per frame (~3–5% render time), improving framerate from ~44 FPS to ~46 FPS in his test scene.

He refactored culling and shadow handling to live in the object itself (rather than geo layout), reducing per-object overhead by “two RAM iterations on every object” and making the engine easier to use for adding shadows/culling radii broadly.
Enemy shadows are currently absent largely due to Fast64 workflow friction; Kaze states that under his newer engine structure, adding enemy shadows everywhere should become straightforward.
Project progress estimate: the hack is “over 70% done,” with roughly “four and a half courses” still missing.

Star Select integration required rethinking menu rendering: Kaze decides to use “one render function per thing” (rather than one geo layout per element) so code can select which geometry/layout to draw dynamically, enabling more flexibility for per-slot animations and variations.

While implementing the new Star Select’s scrolling background, Kaze tracks down a visible seam to an update tick mismatch (speed value aligning with a delayed update), then fixes the “root cause” so the seam disappears.

He discovers a key menu pipeline constraint: some objects/models are not actually loaded at the time Star Select code runs (they appear for a single frame then disappear). He concludes he may need a custom menu segment/asset loading approach, which is “a lot more work than I thought it would.”

The new Star Select text centering problem is traced to using string length without kerning; Kaze switches it to his improved kerning-based measurement, accepting minor remaining inaccuracy until final kerning is fully settled.
findings.quote: I invented better kerning, and this is not used here.

findings.summary: For camera/control schemes, Kaze avoids complex button-combo “tool-like” interactions; he prefers a “one button one output” philosophy to keep gameplay feeling like a game rather than an editor (relevant to his stance on an 8-direction camera concept suggested via another hack).
findings.quote: I don’t want to add any button combos to do stuff because it starts to feel less like a game and more like a tool.

findings.summary: In the Oil Blargg area, Kaze implements a fall-into-oil fade-out + respawn system and iterates on camera behavior to minimize disorientation, aiming to keep the camera angle stable and show where the player died (avoiding the camera going under the oil).

Respawn safety becomes a design/tech problem: he wants to respawn Mario away from edges/geometry exploits, and settles toward validating last-safe ground via distance-to-triangle-edge checks. He uses ChatGPT to generate a triangle edge-distance function, calls it “insane,” and notes it would have been hard to write quickly from memory.
findings.quote: Dude, it fucking works. You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself. And this is why I like ChatGPT.

findings.summary: He explicitly plans to disable this last-safe-position respawn logic on moving objects/platforms, acknowledging that object-based ground introduces edge cases.

He proposes a late-stage polish phase to add VFX/SFX across the game; for the oil hazard specifically, he considers adding an oil-on-Mario effect via a performant overlay approach (rendering a second ‘decal Mario’ with fade in/out), but flags future maintenance cost if additional Mario variants are added.
Kaze reports the current ROM size is around 46 MB (an important constraint/metric for content scope and potential hardware expectations).

Kaze speculates that, with F3DEX3 microcode and extreme optimization (geometry, culling, PVS), an N64 could maybe render parts of Mario Sunshine’s Delfino Plaza at ~30 FPS, but calls water “impossible” without a novel technique.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides the new Star Select visual concept/assets (Blender scene) and gives direct feedback on layout: relative vertical placement of strings/stars/logo, and overall “mood setter” composition. Kaze repeatedly checks ‘is this what you want, Biobak?’ while matching the in-game render to Biobak’s reference video.

Biobak’s Star Select materials/textures include choices that triggered N64 format constraints (e.g., ‘too many unique colors to fit the format’), requiring adjustments like using intensity formats and proper alpha handling.

key_stories.title: Fixing Mario 64 culling math to reclaim performance
key_stories.summary: Kaze identifies that Mario 64’s original culling assumptions don’t match RTYI’s camera/FOV and that the stock code effectively compensates by culling too little. He corrects the culling logic, moves culling/shadow decisions into object code, and measures a meaningful per-frame time reduction and FPS gain.
key_stories.challenge: Performance was being wasted because off-screen objects weren’t being culled aggressively/correctly, and object rendering had avoidable overhead.
key_stories.process: He corrected the culling math to match the actual FOV, then refactored so culling radius and shadow hooks are part of each object’s code path, reducing repeated iterations/overhead.
key_stories.outcome: Measured savings of ~600 microseconds per frame (~3–5%), improving a test scene from ~44 to ~46 FPS and making future shadow/culling additions easier to implement consistently.

key_stories.title: Integrating a new Star Select that behaves like a real-time scene
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements Biobak’s redesigned Star Select screen, wrestling with menu rendering constraints, asset loading timing, scrolling background tiling seams, and text centering. He shifts toward a more flexible rendering architecture to support unique per-slot animations and future changes.
key_stories.challenge: The menu pipeline loads assets differently than levels, causing models to appear for only a frame or not at all; additionally, scrolling backgrounds introduced visible seams and layout mismatches versus the Blender reference.
key_stories.process: He experiments with object spawning and offsets, investigates load order (‘set current level’ vs actual load), considers custom menu segments, fixes the scrolling seam’s tick-delay root cause, and revises text centering by switching from length-based to kerning-based measurement.
key_stories.outcome: Star Select is described as “beautiful” and close to final, with remaining work mainly around pop-in/spawn timing and minor kerning/layout polish.

key_stories.title: Designing a fair respawn for falling into oil without flags/checkpoints
key_stories.summary: While starting Oil Blargg gameplay logic, Kaze implements fade-out and respawn when Mario falls into the oil, but realizes naive respawns can place Mario on edges or inside geometry and can be exploited. He explores a deterministic ‘last safe ground’ approach validated by triangle-edge distance, using ChatGPT to quickly obtain the math routine.
key_stories.challenge: Preventing unfair or exploitable respawns (edge spawns, geometry overlap, progress-by-falling) without adding obvious checkpoint flags or heavy per-frame geometry scans.
key_stories.process: He debates respawn-point volumes vs triangle-based logic, rejects ‘flag/checkpoint’ aesthetics, and settles on storing the last valid position only when Mario is sufficiently far from triangle edges; he asks ChatGPT for the edge-distance algorithm and integrates/testing it.
key_stories.outcome: A working distance-to-edge validator is in place and used to gate saving the last-safe position; next steps include finishing Oil Blargg hitbox/behavior and polishing camera/animation/sound.
key_stories.key_quote: Who has edge detection algorithms memorized?

open_questions.topic: Engine refactor details: object-level culling/shadow system
open_questions.context: Kaze says he moved culling and shadow handling into the object itself (instead of geo layout), saving iterations and making features easier to apply everywhere.
questions: What exactly changed in the object pipeline—what data moved (culling radius, shadow params), and how is it authored now compared to the old Fast64-driven workflow?
What was the optimization he mentioned that ‘doesn’t quite work right now,’ and what’s blocking it?

open_questions.topic: Star Select asset loading and ‘one frame visible’ bug
open_questions.context: During Star Select coding, Kaze notices models appear for one frame and disappear; he realizes the menu code may run before required segments/objects are loaded, implying a need for custom menu segment handling.
questions: What is the exact loading order for the act selector/star select in the decomp, and where did RTYI’s approach conflict with it?
Did you end up implementing a custom menu segment or preloading strategy? If so, what were the tradeoffs (ROM size, RAM, complexity)?
How did Biobak’s Blender reference scene translate into N64 segment/texture constraints (e.g., color limits, material formats)?

open_questions.context: Kaze identifies off-centering caused by length-based measurement without kerning, then switches to his kerning-aware measurement but still expects minor inaccuracies until ‘final kerning.’
questions: What is Kaze’s ‘better kerning’ system technically (data source, per-character widths/pairs), and why wasn’t it used in some UI code paths?
Is the kerning system custom for RTYI fonts only, or generalized for all UI text (mission titles, course names, etc.)?
What remaining text/layout issues are still acceptable placeholders vs must-fix before release?

open_questions.topic: Oil hazard respawn rules and preventing exploits
open_questions.context: Kaze wants oil to cause fade-out + respawn without feeling random, without flags/checkpoints, and without letting players gain progress by falling; he implements triangle edge-distance validation for ‘last safe’ position and plans to disable it on objects/platforms.
questions: What final rules define a ‘valid’ respawn save point (edge distance threshold, triangle size, slope, ceiling/overhang checks)?
How do you guarantee players can’t intentionally ‘save’ a spot that lets them skip intended challenge by falling?
What were the edge cases discovered later (small triangles, thin ledges, moving platforms), and how did you resolve them?

open_questions.topic: Planned polish pass: VFX/SFX and ‘decal Mario’ overlay
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a future polish phase and specifically considers an oil-stain effect via rendering an overlay ‘decal Mario’ with fade in/out, but worries about maintainability if more Mario variants are added.
questions: Did the team end up implementing the ‘decal Mario’ overlay system? If yes, what rendering technique did you use (materials, combiner setup, alpha fades), and what was the performance cost?
How did you decide which hazards get bespoke VFX/SFX (oil, lava, etc.), and how late in development did that pass happen?
What other ‘cheap but high impact’ polish techniques became priorities once performance headroom improved?
